Make your About page about YOU


There are lots of ways to customize your Quarto About page. Here‚Äôs how I did it!



Quarto



Customizing the Quarto About page with text, embeds, and more!





Nov 4, 2023

3 min

‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî


Part 1





No matching items

title: Make your About page about YOU
text:
When I first made my Quarto blog, the first thing I wanted to do was claim it! So here‚Äôs a detailed guide on how to make your About page ABOUT YOU!
Here‚Äôs a link to the Quarto About Page docs.

1Ô∏è‚É£ Claim it
Fill in the YAML at the top. Add your name, your picture, and anything you want to highlight. I have LinkedIn and GitHub, but you can add any Bootstrap 5 icon!
title: <name here>
about:
    image: profile.jpg
    template: jolla
    links:
    - icon: linkedin
      text: LinkedIn
      href: <link to LinkedIn profile here
    - icon: github
      text: Github
      href: <link to GitHub account page here>
You should also describe yourself! Avoid big blocks of text - use bullet points, lists, and unique formatting to make it easy to read (and don‚Äôt forget to use emojis!)
-   üëÄ I'm interested in
-   üíó I'm passionate about
-   üî≠ I'm currently working on ...
-   üå± I'm currently learning ...
-   üíûÔ∏è I'm looking to collaborate on
-   üëØ I'm looking to collaborate on ...
-   ü§î I'm looking for help with ...
-   üí¨ Ask me about ...
-   üì´ How to reach me: ...
-   ‚ö° Fun fact: ...






Tip



If you don‚Äôt want to have bullet points, have two empty spaces at the end of each line to force a line break!


And don‚Äôt forget to add your education and work experience!


2Ô∏è‚É£ Embeds
Quarto is the next evolution of R Markdown, meaning it‚Äôs a markdown file! Anything that can be embedded in markdown (HTML, iframes, etc.) can be embedded in Quarto.
A non-exhaustive list:

Maps
Videos
Tweets
Instagram Posts
Spotify Playlists
GitHub Gists

I decided on 2 Github stats apps, but you can add anything you want!
![GitHub stats](https://github-readme-stats.vercel.app/api?username=<username>&show_icons=true)
![Top Langs](https://github-readme-stats.vercel.app/api/top-langs/?username=<username>&layout=compact)

I also included the icons of my favorite languages and tools using Skill Icons, and some HTML to center it
<p align="center">
  <a href="https://skillicons.dev"> 
    <img src="https://skillicons.dev/icons?i=py,r,md,github,vscode"/> 
  </a>
</p>

  



3Ô∏è‚É£ Templates
Quarto has five templates you can use to make your About page look even better: jolla, trestles, solana, marquee, and broadside. You can see them all here.
I chose jolla because I liked how it was centered like my GitHub stats. To use a template, add the following to your YAML:
about:
  template: solana
If you don‚Äôt like your image being a circle or you don‚Äôt like the size, you can change it to a rectangle by adding the following to your YAML:
about:
  template: marquee
  image-width: 10em
  image-shape: rectangle

title: Make your About page about YOU sub

3Ô∏è‚É£ Templates

title: El Plan
text:
This project is inspired by Mr V‚Äôs Garage.
After watching Mr V‚Äôs video I immediately had a few questions. How would 1950s rules affect the current standings? How would rule changes affect all of the drivers and constructors championships? And most importantly - is there any way for Charles LeClerc to be champion?
To answer these questions requires a system that can automatically fetch race results, clean test and store it, and a way for users explore custom rules. In data engineering terms - a pipeline, a database, and an interactive dashboard.

Architecture & Design
Break problem into components: ingestion, processing, storage, presentation.
Pick tools intentionally and justify them (‚ÄúDataclasses for structured configs‚Äù).
Deliverable: Diagrams, schemas, maybe some pseudocode.





flowchart 
    %% Nodes
    A["‚è∞ Scheduler"]:::process --> B["üèéÔ∏è Pull F1 API Data"]:::process
    B --> C["üßπ Cleaning Script"]:::script
    C --> D["üß™ Data Testing Script"]:::script
    D --> E["üóÑÔ∏è Database (Structured Schema)"]:::data
    E --> F["üìä Streamlit App"]:::app
    F --> G["‚öôÔ∏è User Applies Custom Scoring Rules"]:::app

    %% Classes
    classDef script fill:#d0e7ff,stroke:#3399ff,stroke-width:1px
    classDef data fill:#d0ffd6,stroke:#33cc33,stroke-width:1px
    classDef app fill:#fff7c0,stroke:#ffcc33,stroke-width:1px
    classDef process fill:#f0f0f0,stroke:#999999,stroke-width:1px








Prototype Core Logic
Build the smallest piece of logic independent of data sources (rules engine, algorithm, etc.).
Deliverable: A working Python module, tested in isolation.


Data Acquisition & Cleaning
Bring in external data ‚Üí normalize ‚Üí define your schema.
Deliverable: Clean dataset & documented transformations.


Integration
Connect ingestion + core logic. Test end-to-end flows with small datasets.
Deliverable: Reproducible pipeline.


Interface / Presentation
Build a way to interact with the system (dashboard, API, report).
Deliverable: MVP app.


Iteration & Scalability
Add features, optimize performance, handle edge cases, refactor.
Deliverable: Polished v2.

F1 Custom Points App

title: Putting in the Reps
text:
Post 4: Applying the Rules
Title idea: ‚ÄúCalculating Formula 1 Standings with Custom Rules‚Äù
Purpose: Glue Part 2 (rules) and Part 3 (data).
Content:
Take raw race results.
Apply your PointsRules logic.
Show how different rulesets produce different championship outcomes.
Maybe demonstrate ‚Äúwhat if 2008 was scored by 2024 rules?‚Äù
Deliverable: A reproducible standings calculator.

title: Foundation
text:
Post 2: Setting Up the Foundation
Title idea: ‚ÄúStructuring a Rules Engine in Python with Dataclasses‚Äù
Purpose: Start small, show off clean engineering design.
Content:
Introduce your PointsRules dataclass.
Why you chose dataclasses.
Make a few serialized JSON examples of scoring rules (1980s vs modern).
Maybe a notebook that loads them and prints example points allocations.
Deliverable: A working rules engine, even without race data yet.

title: I feel a need - a need for DATA
text:
Title idea: ‚ÄúPulling Formula 1 Data with the Ergast API‚Äù
Purpose: Bring in external data ‚Üí show you can handle APIs.
Content:
How to connect to the Ergast API (or FastF1 if you want lap times).
Pull one season‚Äôs worth of race results.
Normalize/clean the data into a table you control.
Deliverable: A dataset you can feed into your rules engine.
